chapter.title: Managing Storage
chapter.para: There are several ways of handling disk storage in the Cloud Area Padovana:

listitem.para: Ephemeral storage exists only for the life of a virtual machine instance. It will persist across reboots of the guest operating system but when the instance is deleted so is the associated storage. The size of the ephemeral storage is defined in the virtual machine flavor.

Volumes are persistent virtualized block devices independent of any particular instance. Volumes may be attached to a single instance at a time, but may be detached or reattached to a different instance while retaining all data, much like a USB drive. The size of the volume can be selected when it is created within the quota limits for the particular project.

section.title: Ephemeral storage
section.para: Ephemeral storage exists only for the life of a virtual machine instance. It will persist across reboots of the guest operating system but when the instance is deleted so is the associated storage. The size of the ephemeral storage is defined in the virtual machine flavor.

Among the flavor details (that are listed in the Dashboard when a VM has to be launched or can be seen using the nova flavor-list command), there is an attribute called 'Ephemeral'. When you use a flavor with an ephemeral disk size different from zero, the instance is booted with an extra virtual disk whose size is indicated by the ephemeral value. This ephemeral disk can be useful where you want to partition the second disk or have a specific disk configuration which is not possible within the system disk configuration.

warning.para: Please note that backups are not performed on ephemeral storage systems.

section.title: Volumes
section.para: Volumes are persistent virtualized block devices independent of any particular instance. Volumes may be attached to a single instance at a time (i.e. not like a distributed filesystem such as Lustre or Gluster), but they may be detached or reattached to a different instance while retaining all data, much like a USB drive.
The steps to add a Volume are:

listitem.para: Define a disk volume of the size required (12GB in example below) with the volume name defined (testvol in the example below). Using the Dashboard, click on Volumes and then Create Volume. In the “Create Volume” window specify the name of the volume and the desired size. As Volume Source specify “No source, empty volume”.
The new defined volume will appear in the Volumes tab. To attach this volume to an existing instance, click on Edit attachments and select the relevant Virtual Machine.

section.title: Sharing a volume between multiple (virtual) machines
section.para: Follow the creation and the format of cinder persistent volume above.

Create the mount point and mount the volume:
mkdir /dataNfs mount /dev/sdb /dataNfs

Ensure in your virtual machine designed for nfs server are present the follow rpms and their dependencies:
nfs-utils nfs-utils-lib rpcbind

Insert the corret export in /etc/exports file. For example for all the virtual machine in the same subnet 10.62.15.* (check the subnet with ifconfig command) the contents of the /etc/exports file shoud be:
/dataNfs 10.62.15.*(async,rw,no_root_squash)

Check the iptables on the virtual machine. In the file /etc/sysconfig/iptables ensure other virtaula machines could access to porst 111, 2049, 875 UPD and TPC. So your file /etc/sysconfig/iptables should be like this:
*filter :INPUT ACCEPT [0:0] :FORWARD ACCEPT [0:0] :OUTPUT ACCEPT [0:0] -A INPUT -m state --state ESTABLISHED,RELATED -j ACCEPT -A INPUT -p icmp -j ACCEPT -A INPUT -i lo -j ACCEPT -A INPUT -m state --state NEW -m tcp -p tcp --dport 22 -j ACCEPT -A INPUT -m state --state NEW -m tcp -p tcp --dport 111 -j ACCEPT -A INPUT -m state --state NEW -m udp -p udp --dport 111 -j ACCEPT -A INPUT -m state --state NEW -m tcp -p tcp --dport 875 -j ACCEPT -A INPUT -m state --state NEW -m udp -p udp --dport 875 -j ACCEPT -A INPUT -m state --state NEW -m tcp -p tcp --dport 2049 -j ACCEPT -A INPUT -m state --state NEW -m udp -p udp --dport 2049 -j ACCEPT -A INPUT -j REJECT --reject-with icmp-host-prohibited -A FORWARD -j REJECT --reject-with icmp-host-prohibited COMMIT
Remember to restart iptables after any change on that file:
/etc/init.d/iptables restart

Enter in another instance of the same tentant and mount via nfs filesystem like example below (if some errors occurs check you have installed rpcbind):
mount -t nfs 10.62.15.4:/dataNfs /mnt
